pred: SUMMARY: Students found the light bulb demonstrations engaging and helpful in understanding abstract concepts. The separation of charges demonstration was particularly intriguing, providing a visual representation of invisible forces at work. The interactive nature of these demonstrations, allowing students to observe and question, was appreciated, with some students expressing that they learn best through such practical examples.
input:
The conservation of energy question was very tricky. I was indecisive between the correct answer and the “difference in charge” answer, so I felt that I learned the most from this question.
The explanation of your plastic sheet and lightbulb experiment was really neat and caught my interests. 
I thought having the visual examples was interesting because it makes topics easier to understand.
I found it interesting how similar electric force is to gravitational force. 
I found the demonstration done to show the lightbulb lighting was very interesting because of the separation of charges.
The group work in solving the distribution of charge
What I found most interesting today was that there can be two components of an electrostatic force. I found this interesting because  I'm working with forces that are invisible. 
Energy conservation in particle physics with a gamma ray photon being split into an electron and positron was very intriguing since I've never learned much about gamma rays in the past.
The amount of interaction we were able to have with you as an instructor and in breakout rooms was interesting.
I thought the demonstration with the lightbulb was fun to watch. It gave me a visual representation of what was happening.
 I found interesting how similar the forces caused by charges and gravity are. 
 I like that the math is pretty consistent and the laws and theorems are pretty easily definable I just get messed up when you're doing demonstrations that move really quickly and the words go over my head.
 I found the clicker question about F and F' very interesting.
 The shell theory was a very interesting concept and easy to understand because it is so similar to how you treat round objects in translational motion which helped me understand it better
 i really like learning about the electric charges and i like learning about electrons after taking so many chemistry classes 
 The final question about charges on the corners of a square. 
 The demonstration in the beginning was interesting. I like it better when I can see what is happening.
 I found that the different ways charges spread out was interesting and I understood the differences between all of the examples of them
 I enjoyed doing the practice problems because I believe that is the best way to learn. 
 Electric charge properties 
 I found the Part 5: Charges Spread Out video the most interesting! The first one of 50:50 seemed to be expected but I found the grounded conductor and induced charge to be interesting

I thought having the visual examples was interesting because it makes topics easier to understand.
I found the demonstration done to show the lightbulb lighting was very interesting because of the separation of charges.
I thought the demonstration with the lightbulb was fun to watch. It gave me a visual representation of what was happening.
The demonstration in the beginning was interesting. I like it better when I can see what is happening.

   *Revised*: "Students found the light bulb demonstrations engaging and visually informative, providing a tangible representation of abstract concepts."

2. **Highlight Unique Aspects**: Emphasize the unique aspects of the demonstrations that students found particularly helpful, such as the separation of charges demonstration. This will make the summary more focused on the specific topic of light bulb demonstrations.

   *Original*: "The interactive nature of these demonstrations, allowing students to observe and question, was appreciated..."

   *Revised*: "The demonstrations, particularly the separation of charges using a light bulb, offered students a unique opportunity to observe and understand invisible forces at work."

3. **Avoid Generalizing**: Instead of saying "students found" or "students appreciated," use specific student quotes to illustrate their points. This will make the summary more engaging and directly reflect the students' voices.

   *Original*: "Students found the light bulb demonstrations engaging..."

pred: **SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on electric charges engaging, with key takeaways including the tricky yet educational conservation of energy question, and the captivating demonstration of charge separation using a lightbulb. The similarity between electric and gravitational forces sparked interest, as did the introduction to the two components of electrostatic force. The interactive nature of the lecture, including group work and instructor interaction, was appreciated. The consistent mathematical approach and easily definable laws were praised, while some students found rapid demonstrations challenging. The shell theory and properties of electric charges were well-received, with videos and visual examples aiding understanding.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Gaussian surface concept challenging, with key areas of confusion including choosing appropriate Gaussian surface shapes (any shape possible? Multiple shapes for the same answer?), and the distinction between conductors and insulators in relation to Gauss' law. They also struggled with calculating areas of complex shapes like cylinders and understanding how charge distribution (positive/negative, inside/outside) affects flux. Some students found specific problems, like the right-angle planes and uniformly charged inner sphere, difficult to grasp. More examples and slower problem-solving in class were suggested to enhance understanding.
input:
i think the last practice problem we did in class could've been done slower to make it easier to comprehend. i had to think it over for a few minutes after class ended for it to come to me
I did not understand why the electric field inside of a solid, uniform, insulating sphere (r<R) is greater than the field outside of it (r>R).
I think the angle at which flux flows from an object is a bit confusing. The first problem on the concept quiz deals with this. 
I think the idea and concepts make sense, but I am confused about what shapes to choose as the Gaussian surface. Can you choose any shape? Are there multiple shapes that will still give the same answer as the cylinder? Also, the conductor vs insulator in reference to Gauss' law is confusing to me
The orientation of planar electric fields and cylindrical Gaussian surface
More examples would be helpful for further understanding. 
Figuring out what Gaussian surface to draw in problems 
I was not too confused but the field lines of the right angle planes question for the quiz was confusing. 
Nothing was too confusing. The only part I found a little difficult was the different gauss fields around the uniformly charged inner sphere. Just transitioning from one layer to the next for me slightly confused in your last example problem video.
I was confused about why we find the areas of the three different parts of the cylinder, and how we do this.
 The second question on the concept quiz confused me, I wasn't sure how positive and negative charges being outside or inside affect flux.
 Are these the only three symmetries we will work with?

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the Versatility of Gaussian Surface Shapes**: To improve the summary, explicitly mention that while any shape can be chosen as a Gaussian surface, students are encouraged to select simple, symmetrical shapes to simplify calculations. This addresses the confusion about choosing shapes and the possibility of multiple shapes yielding the same answer.

   *Revised sentence*: "Students were reminded that any shape can serve as a Gaussian surface, but simple, symmetrical shapes are preferred for ease of calculation."

2. **Distinguish Conductors and Insulators in Relation to Gauss' Law**: To make this point more concise, focus on the key difference between conductors and insulators in the context of Gauss' law, i.e., the electric field inside a conductor is zero, unlike insulators where the electric field can be non-zero.

   *Revised sentence*: "Students found it helpful to distinguish between conductors (where the electric field inside is zero) and insulators (where the electric field can be non-zero) in relation to Gauss' law."

3. **Simplify the Calculation of Areas and Understanding of Charge Distribution**: To make this point more focused, emphasize that students struggled with calculating areas of complex shapes and understanding how the position (inside/outside) and sign (positive/negative) of charges affect the flux through a Gaussian surface.

   *Revised sentence*: "Students found calculating areas of complex shapes and understanding the impact of charge position and sign on flux through a Gaussian surface challenging."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the Gaussian surface concept challenging, with key areas of confusion. They were reminded that any shape can serve as a Gaussian surface, but simple, symmetrical shapes are preferred for ease of calculation. Students found it helpful to distinguish between conductors (where the electric field inside is zero) and insulators (where the electric field can be non-zero) in relation to Gauss' law. Calculating areas of complex shapes and understanding the impact of charge position and sign on flux through a Gaussian surface proved challenging for students. More examples and slower problem-solving in class were suggested to enhance understanding.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on resistors/resistance engaging, particularly the practical applications and real-world connections. They appreciated learning about calculating resistance in series and parallel circuits, with some noting the analogy to finding voltage. The concept of batteries losing voltage over time and having internal resistance was also interesting. Students found the practice problems beneficial for exam preparation and enjoyed applying physics concepts to everyday objects like batteries.
input:

All of the different ways to use Ohm's Law by rearranging the equation
I found circuits interesting because I am able to see how it is used in real life very often. 
I thought it was nice at how easy calculating resistance was after proving with algebra that the resistors in series can just be additively calculated 
Ohms law

 Power and how it relates to resistors

 The circuits in general are interesting.

 Applying physics concepts to real life applications

 the relation to energy and the combination of many past concepts

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Redundancy**: Combine similar points to make the summary more concise. For instance, merge the points about calculating resistance in series and parallel, and the real-world application of circuits.

2. **Focus on Key Concepts**: Highlight the key concepts of resistors/resistance that students found most interesting and helpful, such as the additive calculation for series resistors and the flipped analogy for parallel resistors.

3. **Clarify the Battery Point**: Instead of mentioning batteries losing voltage over time and having internal resistance separately, combine them into a single point about the non-ideal behavior of real-world batteries.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students engaged with the resistors/resistance lecture, appreciating its practical applications and real-world connections. They found calculating resistance in series (additively) and in parallel (inversely, akin to finding voltage) particularly insightful. The concept of real-world batteries having internal resistance and not maintaining their rated voltage over time was also intriguing. Students valued the practice problems for exam preparation and enjoyed applying physics to everyday objects like batteries.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of integrals, particularly in calculating potential energy and electric fields, challenging. Many struggled with setting up problems, choosing appropriate bounds, and understanding when to set the initial potential to zero. Some also expressed confusion about the difference between voltage potential energy and regular potential energy. To enhance understanding, students suggested more examples, explanations, and whole-class clarification for integral setups and electric field calculations.
input:
The integral part and the last problem that we did. I am always confused about how to set up the problem.
I was mostly confused about how to pick bounds for the integral in solving for potential energy. Ultimately, my answer for a question was wrong Bc I chose wrongly.
Today's class was really great! For once I felt like I was following along with everything, and understanding the material. The explanation from finding electric potential from electric field could have been explained a little more, I feel.
The practice problem with the integral needed more details in today's class. I needed more clarification in a group of the whole class rather than my breakout room. 
the last top hat question could've had more explanation. i was confused on how to set it up
I was confused how to find work using an integral when one of the bounds was zero. 
Trying to figure out what dq should equal while integrating

The concept addressed in the second concept question, regarding how fields are affected by other fields, was confusing. 
I was confused about how to take partial derivatives, and when it makes sense to do so.
 The difference between the voltage potential energy, the potential energy and then regular volatage. I just kept getting lost with the symbols and meanings
 Overall more examples, not necessarily solving but the setup, would be helpful as well as more explanation of dipoles and their potential energy 
 The potential energy of the field was confusing. 
 The second question on the second concept quiz was about conductors. If you could explain the answer in class that would be great. I cannot seem to wrap my head around it. 
 I didn't find anything really confusing, but I think it would be helpful to look at calculating potential from an electric field again

input:
I found it interesting using the loop rule to solve the last problem because it made the problem more simple than I initially thought. 
i liked that no matter which path you took to find current in a circuit, you'll get the same value. 
The computer circuit was the most interesting part of class today because I would never be able to understand that in my life. 
Grounding and how it changes the calculation for current
I found the part where the professor left the class as funny. It really gave us all a break in the middle
Current here split up when you add grounded points to a circuit 
Batteries and circuits are intriguing. I like to learn about currents and how energy within batteries work
The circuit analysis about the voltage in loops summing to 0. 
I found the ammeters and voltmeters interesting because they can both be used in the same circuit but for different reasons. 
I thought your explanation of ammeters and voltmeters was very well done. This topic that was previously confusing to me in high school is now much clearer. I thought it was interesting thinking about how current runs through a wire and why each of these have to have very different resistances.
 I've used multimeters before. But never considered that just measuring would impact the circuit itself so your reading will never be 100% true. Was just a little interesting and never thought about it before. since the meter will just extend the circuit and draw some energy.  neat. 
 Internal resistance 
 I found the videos explaining the concepts most interesting.
 The grounding was very interesting. 
 How ammeters and voltmeters play a role in circuits 
 Learning how voltmeters are able to get accurate voltage readings without leaking much current out of the circuit by being connected in parallel with resistors/capacitors.
 I thought grounding was interesting. I never understood what grounding meant before. 
 Voltmeters and ammeters are really interesting in that I think it's cool that we can actually measure these concepts (voltage and current) pretty easily
 Learning the paths circuits take and what way the current flows I found to be very interesting. It's cool to see how current flows in real wires and in real life. 
 i thought that the applications of grounding and how that could simplify complicated circuits was interesting 
 I thought the ammeter and voltmeter were the most interesting part, especially after the concept quiz and seeing how the voltmeter was the emf
 I thought it was interesting that all grounded points are connected to each other.
 The amount of info we can determine from a simple circuit with proper analysis is very cool.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on flux engaging and accessible, with many finding the concept easy to grasp after watching video lectures in advance. The Faraday cage demonstration was particularly captivating, illustrating how insulators and conductors react to electric fields, and how flux can be manipulated to cancel out external fields. The electric flux portion was well-received, with students appreciating the use of diagrams and the opportunity to solve problems involving charge. Gauss's Law was highlighted as a useful tool for simplifying complex problems, and the idea of measuring flux through a dot product was found to be surprisingly straightforward. Students also appreciated the practical applications of flux, such as determining the charge of a surface and calculating the charge enclosed in an area. While some students still felt they needed more practice to solidify their understanding, overall, the lecture was well-received and helped clarify many students' confusion about the topic.
input:
I really like the flux topic. The concept questions about these were something that I found relatively easy to answer after watching the lecture videos in advance. 
The faraday cage video was really interesting.
It was interesting to see the way that insulators and conductors reacted to electric fields and how that affected the flux
I found Faraday cages cancelling out external electric fields very interesting. It was also neat how the internal cap of a cylinder imbedded in a conductor has no flux, but the external end does.
I liked the electric flux portion of the lecture this week. I liked reading the diagrams and solving for the charge in the example with the box. 
Flux and field lines with Gaussian 
I found Gauss's Law interesting based on the fact that it can simplify a very difficult problem
I find it interesting that such a complex value like flux can be measured by a dot product and not a more complicated calculus method. 
The diagrams helped me picture how flux works
I found GaussIan surfaces pretty interesting since you can draw a shape and then make solving Gauss' law easier to solve.
 conductors 
 How we can use field lines to determine the charge of a surface

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on integrals engaging, particularly how they simplify through constant pulling and substitution. input:
i thought it was really cool to see the integrations and see how one subject goes to the other
How the integrals simplify as you pull out constants and make substitutions. 
How the Calculus concepts were applied to extended charges (integrals, u-substitution)
I found it interesting that a single sliver of a rod or ring with uniform charge can be used to calculate the entire electric field produced by the object
I found that integration is very useful to solve problems in physics. It helped me translate skills from calculus to solve problems in physics.
Example problems
I enjoyed the fact that we kept going into breakout rooms in small intervals. It helped us bounce ideas off each other.
I found the integrals interesting because it matches up with what I am doing in math class right now. 
The checking as a point charge and line charge
i found that the different charge densities were  interesting

 I found it interesting how calculus integrates into physics. It was cool to see how the integral can be used to calculate an electric field. 
 I found most interesting how we can use integration to determine the electric field
 Compared to the ring of charge, the line of charge is pretty simple and easy to understand
 The mathematical formulas that define abstract electrical concepts are really interesting.
 I found it interesting how an integral can be used to calculate any shape of forces. 
 I love math especially calculus so to see any type is always refreshing. I always enjoy seeing when both are involved in each other (I'm learning some physics in calc 3 right now too)

I found the balloon tophat question most interesting about today's class because I thought too hard about it at first and once it was explained it was an “ah” moment
I found the balloon example interesting because it tied what we were learning to a more real world experience/possibility 
The rc circuit stuff
The equation for magnetic fields on point chargesThe equation for magnetic fields on point charges
It's interesting how the current of an RC circuit is essentially a fraction of the original current dependant on the time constant. 
I enjoy learning about magnets, their properties and their fields
I found the magnetic field lines interesting because no matter how small they get they will always have a north and a south end. 
I thought it was really interesting that capacitors ALL charge at the same “rate” which is RC seconds. Also found it interesting that capacitors are never fully charged. the graph was a good representation of this since I feel most of us are very familiar what an asymptote is and what it represents as a graphical function 
Magnetic field lines and  multiloop circuits 
 The rc time unit was interesting. 
 I really like that magnetic field lines follow the same rules as electric field lines. I also like that magnetic monopoles haven't been discovered! 
 How you can split up multi loop circuits into separate branches 
 I really enjoyed writing the circuit equations in terms of one another and then forming differential equations. On top of already enjoying this unit, I really like this kind of math as well
 It was neat how we used the very basic loop rule to build up to a separable differential equation that solves q(t).
 I thought it was interesting how we have never been able to create a magnet with the same poles. Especially since it has the possibility to be useful for technology. 
 It's interesting how electrons move in circular motion around a magnetic field. Also it is interesting how many times we use the cross product. 
 I found it interesting that magnetic fields are so similar to electric fields.
 I think it is interesting how the graphs of charging and discharging a capacitor are able to tell us a lot
 Direction of vectors 
 How the magnetic field acts 
 Magnetism's ability to affect a charge. 
 I found it interesting how we are calculating the voltage and charges for real life circuits.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Redundancy**: Combine similar student reflections to make the summary more concise. For instance, multiple students found the concept of current decay over time interesting, so you could simply state that "Students found the concept of current decay over time, dependent on the time constant 'RC', engaging and insightful."

2. **Highlight Key Concepts**: Emphasize the key concepts that students found interesting. Instead of mentioning the balloon example as a real-world application, highlight the specific concept it illustrated, such as "Students appreciated understanding the practical application of RC circuits through the demonstration of capacitor charging and discharging, represented by the equation q(t) = Q(1 - e^(-t/RC))."

3. **Clarify Mathematical Aspects**: To keep the summary focused on RC circuits and avoid generic statements, specify which mathematical aspects students found interesting. Instead of "the mathematical aspect", mention "deriving and solving differential equations for circuit equations, such as q(t) = Q(1 - e^(-t/RC)), was well-received."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the RC circuit topic engaging, with the concept of current decay over time, dependent on the time constant 'RC', being particularly insightful. They appreciated understanding the practical application of RC circuits through the demonstration of capacitor charging and discharging, represented by the equation q(t) = Q(1 - e^(-t/RC)). Students also found deriving and solving differential equations for circuit equations, such as q(t) = Q(1 - e^(-t/RC)), to be well-received.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on magnetism and magnetic fields engaging, with the balloon top hat question and real-world applications, such as the RC circuit and capacitor charging, sparking particular interest. The consistent rules between electric and magnetic field lines, the absence of magnetic monopoles, and the mathematical approach to circuit equations were also highlighted as intriguing aspects. The students' reflections indicated a strong grasp of the topic's fundamental concepts and a keen interest in its practical applications.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Redundancy**: Combine similar points to make the summary more concise. For instance, merge the reflections on magnetic field lines and their comparison with electric field lines.
   - *Original*: "I really like that magnetic field lines follow the same rules as electric field lines. I also like that magnetic monopoles haven't been discovered!"
   - *Revised*: "Students appreciated the similarity between magnetic and electric field lines and found the absence of magnetic monopoles intriguing."

2. **Highlight Key Concepts**: Emphasize the most significant ideas from the reflections to better focus the summary on magnetism/magnetic fields.
   - *Original*: "The rc time unit was interesting."
   - *Revised*: "Students found the concept of time constant (τ = RC) in RC circuits particularly interesting."

3. **Clarify Student Interest**: Make the summary more engaging by clearly stating what specifically sparked students' interest in the topic.
   - *Original*: "The consistent rules between electric and magnetic field lines..."
   - *Revised*: "Students were captivated by discovering the consistent rules and behaviors of magnetic field lines, mirroring those of electric field lines."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on magnetism and magnetic fields engaging, with real-world applications such as the RC circuit and capacitor charging sparking particular interest. They were captivated by discovering the consistent rules and behaviors of magnetic field lines, mirroring those of electric field lines, and found the absence of magnetic monopoles intriguing. The concept of time constant (τ = RC) in RC circuits and the mathematical approach to circuit equations, including the use of differential equations, were also highlighted as intriguing aspects. Students appreciated the practical applications of magnetism and expressed curiosity about its potential technological uses, indicating a strong grasp of the topic's fundamental concepts and a keen interest in its real-world implications.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Shell Theorem and Coulomb's Law informative, with some areas of confusion. The diagrams and examples were generally clear, but the interpretation of diagrams and specific mathematical steps caused some difficulty. The Shell Theorem, in particular, was confusing for many students, with some struggling to understand the difference between the two theorems and others not grasping the concept of grounding. A few students felt that the pace was rushed, especially in the initial explanation of charges, and some wished for more in-depth explanations or Q&A sessions. Overall, students appreciated the interactive problem-solving periods and found the lecture engaging.
input:
n/a
Much was very thorough and clear. I had some issues understanding the diagrams at first, not sure why. Seems a few others were confused with how to interpret the diagram as well. Nevertheless, it was a good self problem solving period. and when the prof explained, it was clear and well executed. I understood more being confused and then being enlightened and shown how the diagram was supposed to represent the particles and their charges. furthermore, after the first diagram it seemed like I felt I was absorbing s a lotmore from the concepts you were trying to get through to us.
I think the example pertaining to the charges arranged in a square was a little confusing. Particularly deriving the r value.
I thought that everything was very clear, however I felt that some of the time given for the TopHat questions was insufficient. There were multiple times where I scrambled to put in an answer that ended up being wrong because I was one or two steps away from the right answer but didn't have time to finish the problem. 
What I found unclear was the lightbulb lighting up due to the work done by the professor. It was stated that the work done caused the lightbulb to light up and the electrons moving into the lightbulb.
The uses for coulombs law in specific 
In today's class the Shell theorem was very confusing to me. I did not understand how it works. 
The idea of grounding was unclear to me. I did not understand how charge can be left over in a particle after it has been grounded.
Overall, today's class was really good! I thought that each tophat question was well explained. I was a little confused with some of the math steps you took in simplifying, because you never showed any conversions, but the whole concept was clear.
I thought some of the problems we did in class were confusing. I did end up finding the right answers but I think the explanation in class could've been more in-depth.
 I was a bit confused with the concept question on tophat about the ratio of charges, but after explaining, it made more sense. 
 I really didn't understand the second top hat question with the two particles that were repelling eachother and then a third particle touches both of them respectively. I know how the first particle touches the third particle so it's q value and the first particles q value are halved. I also know how the second particle touches the third particle and doing (1/2+1)/2 is 3/4 for both particles. I just didn't know where to go from there to solve for F' or F because I didn't know what it defined as F' and F. You probably mentioned it though and it just went too quickly for me. 
 I was confused about how the energy from Dr. Nero was what caused the lightbulb to light up in the experiment.
 The beginning of the lecture about charges was a bit rushed and I think it would be a valuable thing to go over since it is the building blocks of electric forces
 i enjoyed today's class. i struggled when all the forces were being applied onto the one force. i didn't understand this because i couldn't seem to figure out why that one force just became 0. 
 I think today's class was good. The breakout rooms did help me meet some new students. I was also able to understand the content well, as I solved the questions on my own before the professor. It would be great if we could have Q n A sometime during lecture. 
 I was confused about the way to break up the components in the last problem. I forgot about vector math from physics 1. The breakout room for one of the problems was not helpful, my group did not participate.
 I was a little bit confused on Shell Theorems in today's class because the two Theorems seem to be very similar and I'm having trouble understanding the difference between the two. 
 I felt that the lecture was well explained. I believe that one would only find it confusing if they didn't watch the prerecorded lectures before hand. 
 Coulomb's law Shell Theorems
 I found the second shell theorem to be confusing. Is there no electric force on the particle because the shell it is in is charged?
cluster:

I was a little bit confused on Shell Theorems in today’s class because the two Theorems seem to be very similar and I’m having trouble understanding the difference between the two.
Coulomb’s law Shell Theorems
I found the second shell theorem to be confusing. Is there no electric force on the particle because the shell it is in is charged?
suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the confusion on Shell Theorem**: Instead of mentioning "the Shell Theorem, in particular, was confusing for many students," specify that students struggled with understanding the difference between the two theorems and the concept of grounding within the Shell Theorem. This provides more targeted information for the instructor.

2. **Highlight the need for clear mathematical steps**: Rather than a general mention of "specific mathematical steps," emphasize that students had difficulty following the steps in deriving the 'r' value in the square charge arrangement example and in vector math for the last problem. This will help the instructor focus on these areas in future lectures.

3. **Recommend a recap of fundamental concepts**: Instead of suggesting a slower pace, propose a brief recap of fundamental concepts like charges at the beginning of the lecture. This will help students better understand the building blocks of electric forces and reduce confusion throughout the lecture.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on Shell Theorem and Coulomb's Law informative, with specific areas of confusion. While diagrams and examples were generally clear, students struggled with interpreting diagrams and following certain mathematical steps. Notably, students had difficulty understanding the difference between the two Shell Theorems and the concept of grounding within the Shell Theorem. Additionally, deriving the 'r' value in the square charge arrangement example and applying vector math in the last problem caused confusion. To improve understanding, a brief recap of fundamental concepts like charges at the beginning of the lecture would be beneficial. Students appreciated the interactive problem-solving periods and found the lecture engaging overall.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of Ohm's Law challenging, particularly in series and parallel circuits. They struggled with determining the split of current in parallel circuits and adding voltages in series. Visual aids, like diagrams, were suggested to enhance understanding of emf and voltage differences. The relationship between current, voltage, and resistance, as well as the distinction between internal and external voltages, also caused confusion. While some students grasped the concept well, others found power calculations and the role of resistors in circuits confusing.
input:
I was a little confused about the last example in lecture for finding the voltage in each resistor because I wasn't sure how the amps split in the circuit
Re-drawing and simplifying circuits is still a bit confusing
I found resistors in series fairly confusing just because I find myself getting tripped up with how to add voltage in the series. 
I think find emf and voltage difference could be gone over a little more. Maybe an example with a diagram instead of graph would benefit us more conceptually 
Resistors 
I found the example of discharging a real battery a bit confusing as it is hard to recognize R and r. 
The group problems
I thought the examples at the end of the cuvids for the first set were a little confusing, I wasn't sure how the equations were derived
The conceptual tophat questions about current vs voltage were most confusing for me because I don't fully understand the relationship between the two. 
I think I actually understood this one well. The only thing I truly struggled was the second part with the battery, the E and the delta V
 Trying to figure out if things are in series or parallel
 For the first time ever in this class I feel like I actually understand all the cuvids for this section.
 I'd say power was the most confusing part. 
 Relating delta V=emf to delta V=IR
 I found it confusing how and what resistors actually do.  I find it confusing because I am doing calculations and finding numbers but don't know what they do. 
 More examples and discussion of differences between conductors, semiconductors etc 
 I was confused about how you can tell when resistors are in parallel/series
 It wasn't confusing, but I think going over Ohm's law and when you can and can't use it would be helpful 
 the relationship between the internal voltage of a battery vs. the external voltage.

Additionally, students were confused about the relationship between the voltage supplied by a battery and the voltage across its terminals. Some students found the conceptual relationship between current and voltage and the application of Ohm's law difficult. To enhance understanding, students suggested more interactive examples or group activities that discuss the differences between various types of resistors and their roles in circuits.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on capacitors largely clear, with some areas of confusion. The most prevalent concerns were understanding charge density and its relationship with current density and electric field, as well as the distinction between capacitors in series and parallel. Several students were puzzled by the method used to combine capacitances in a circuit, particularly the addition of non-matching capacitances. Visualizing and conceptualizing these topics, especially the difference between parallel and series capacitance formulas, was also challenging for some. Lastly, a few students sought clarification on the definition of equivalent capacitance.
input:
honestly everything was pretty clear today! maybe the lightning part could have been a little more clear, but if you were really paying attention it made sense!
The only thing I felt was kind of confusing was charge density. In lecture, you said that current density and the electric field went in opposite directions and I found that slightly perplexing.
What the units represented in the context of each other.
Simplifying circuit diagrams by re-orienting capacitors is still a bit unclear to me when there are many different branches involved.
The current density was the most confusing for me because I was just a bit confused on how to set up the integral. 
I'm a little confused on how charge is distributed on capacitors in series vs capacitors in parallel. 
Series capacitors and resistance 
Deciding between parallel and series 
I thought that it was a little confusing why in the 1st example you performed you added the non matching capacitance (C3) with C2 and plugged that into the expression. and on our sapling concept quiz, we instead used expression (C1*C2)/(C1+C2)+ C3.  why were we allowed to do that for that problem and not this one? genuinely confused. 
I was confused about how you know when capacitors are in parallel with each other.
 The equation for Fnet using drift velocity
 I'm having trouble conceptualizing and visualizing these topics so examples and explanations of concepts would help. Also, how is electric current/density acts in insulators
 The difference in using the formula c1*c2/c1+c2 vs using the equation for parallel capacitance or series capacitance confuses me a bit on the concept quiz. 
 I found it confusing defining what C equivalence was.
cluster:

I'm a little confused on how charge is distributed on capacitors in series vs capacitors in parallel.
Series capacitors and resistance
I thought that it was a little confusing why in the 1st example you performed you added the non matching capacitance (C3) with C2 and plugged that into the expression. and on our sapling concept quiz, we instead used expression (C1*C2)/(C1+C2)+ C3.  why were we allowed to do that for that problem and not this one? genuinely confused.
I was confused about how you know when capacitors are in parallel with each other.
The difference in using the formula c1*c2/c1+c2 vs using the equation for parallel capacitance or series capacitance confuses me a bit on the concept quiz.
I found it confusing defining what C equivalence was.
suggestion:
Suggestions:

1. **Combine Similar Concerns**: Merge the confusion about charge density and its relation to current density and electric field into a single point to make the summary more concise. For example, "Students struggled to grasp the relationship between charge density, current density, and electric field."

2. **Clarify Capacitor Connection Method**: Break down the confusion about combining capacitances into two specific points to provide more focus:
   - "Students were unclear about the method to combine non-matching capacitances in a circuit."
   - "The distinction between using the formula for parallel and series capacitance caused confusion among students."

3. **Remove Less Prevalent Concerns**: To maintain focus on the most significant issues, consider removing or combining the following points:
   - "Visualizing and conceptualizing these topics" could be merged with the previous points.
   - "The difference in using the formula C1*C2/(C1+C2) vs using the equation for parallel or series capacitance" could be combined with the previous point about the confusion in combining capacitances.
   - "Clarification on the definition of equivalent capacitance" could be merged with the confusion about combining capacitances.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the capacitors lecture mostly clear, with key areas of confusion. Notably, they struggled to grasp the relationship between charge density, current density, and electric field. Students were unclear about the method to combine non-matching capacitances in a circuit and the distinction between using the formula for parallel and series capacitance, causing confusion in circuit analysis. Visualizing and conceptualizing these topics, particularly the difference in capacitance formulas, remained challenging for some.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found several aspects of electric and uniform fields challenging. Calculating dipole moments outside uniform fields and understanding the relationship between electric fields and forces were common areas of confusion. The application of dipoles in uniform fields, particularly their behavior near charged plates, also caused difficulty. Some students struggled with the binomial theorem and simple charge distributions, while others found the potential energy of dipoles unclear. A few students suggested slowing down during practice problems to better absorb information.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the "Monkey Problem" engaging and thought-provoking, with many citing it as the most interesting part of the lecture. They appreciated the real-world application of projectile motion and the counterintuitive concept that aiming at the monkey while it's falling ensures a hit. Visual aids, such as the video demonstrating the problem, were particularly helpful in understanding and visualizing the physics involved. The problem also reinforced the independence of horizontal and vertical motion in projectile motion, a key concept many students found intriguing.
input:
I liked the top hat questions. I feel they are engaging and make it easier to learn material.
I found the monkey problem interesting because it proves a real world situation with our understanding of projectile motion
top hat questions as they help me not zone out during class
I find it interesting that if you were to shoot a bullet straight up, out of a car that was traveling at a constant speed, the bullet would eventually come back and hit the car.
I though the most interesting part was how when 2 ojects are mid air travel, gravity cancels out since they are both experienceing it the same, regardless of the x value
I found that the relative velocity problems pretty interesting. I've always had a bit of trouble understanding the problems, but it made a lot more sense once it was explained and ibwas able to get the tophat relative velocity question correct.
I thought projectile motion was interesting because I learned that vertical and horizontal motions are independent. Although the x component's velocity is constant, the y component's velocity is not.
the monkey experiment that was shown 
I think the most interesting thing was the various projectile practice problems because they were fun to do, and since I'd already covered kinematics earlier, doing new things was fun.

3. **Use Quotations**: Incorporate direct quotes from students to provide a stronger impact. For example, "One student found the 'monkey problem' 'fascinating' as it demonstrated a real-world application of projectile motion."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found TopHat questions engaging and kept them focused throughout the lecture. They particularly appreciated the "monkey problem," with one student calling it "fascinating" for its real-world application of projectile motion. The "relative velocity problems" also resonated with students, with one noting, "It made a lot more sense once it was explained and I was able to get the TopHat question correct." The interactive nature of these questions allowed students to actively participate and reinforce their understanding of the material.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on vector addition engaging, with the interactive format, use of breakout rooms, and TopHat questions fostering collaboration and engagement. The concept of vector addition, particularly by components, was highlighted as interesting and useful, with real-life applications like the hockey puck and yeti problems making the topic more relatable. Students appreciated the clear steps involved in vector addition and the multiple methods demonstrated, such as using triangles and trigonometry. The ability to determine direction and magnitude using vector addition was also noted as fascinating.
input:
The format. I've never had a flipped class like this one so it was unusual to have the small time for review and then immediately in to problem solving. I've also never heard vector addition described with the principle of moving backwards along one arrow and that that's why you subtract it (rather than in reference to the idea that origin doesn't matter and therefore whatever the starting location is should be subtracted out from every piece)
It was very entertaining which makes it a lot easier to pay attention too
I think the most interesting part was the use of break out rooms to allow the students to collaborate on a problem
I thought vector additions was the most interesting because of the easy system of steps that need to be followed to solve problems. I really like when things are laid out clearly and the steps are easy to follow. 
I enjoyed when we got to work on the problem in groups of 4. It allowed for discussion between classmates.
The most interesting material in this lecture was using unit vectors to easily add each component of a vector to find its total length.
I found the hockey question interesting because it was challenging but after working in groups we were able to figure it out
I enjoyed going over answers and work during the breakout room session for the one top hat question.
I found adding and subtracting 3 vectors interesting 
I thought it was interesting that cos(x) usually applies to the x-axis, but it's relative to your perspective
 The fact that with the knowledge of vectors you can identify the force and direction of an object being acted on by multiple forces going in different directions.
 I really liked the problem that we did in breakout rooms. This was a good use of time because it allowed for my peers and I to think for ourselves and still be able to get help if needed
 How the vector notations can simplify in multiple dimensions to create either a vector or scalar output.
 I liked the way the professor described vector addition as adding a negative vector. I have never been taught i that way, and it makes vector subtraction much easier.
 I liked getting to use top hat during class and getting put into the break out rooms. I think that it made class more interesting and helped to keep me engaged in what was going on. 
 The thing that I found most interesting was the way he explained how to get the answer and how he showed multiple ways of getting to the answer.
 I was most interested by the break out groups because it allowed us to work on the question together. If one person was stuck we could ask another for help and it's nice to have a peer help sometimes because they have a different viewpoint from the professor or TAs.
 The problem prompts were not boring. 
 How word problems are so easily connected to the topic, and how much easier it is to understand a problem when you draw out the vectors. 
 I really enjoyed doing the TopHat questions in groups. I enjoyed working with others and it felt good helping others with the problem
 I thought it was interesting seeing how, what we learned in the recorded videos, could actually apply to real life situations. 
 The idea that a yeti cannot determine its way and somehow needs the help of gps technology.
 I was able to piece together how to solve the problems we were doing at the end of the lecture and it was satisfying to see myself come to understand how to solve them by the end
 I really enjoyed the way class was formatted! I like that we aren't just repeating the book/notes we took ahead of time. I am fully engaged in practice problems, and thus find them more interesting.
 I found it interesting how much the content overlaps what I'm learning in calculus right now. 
 I like math, so I find setting up vector problems using triangles to be a bit fun.

 I loved how you outlined your teaching style!  It was awesome to get insight into how you want to run the class.

input:
The format. I've never had a flipped class like this one so it was unusual to have the small time for review and then immediately in to problem solving. I think the most interesting part was the use of break out rooms to allow the students to collaborate on a problem
I thought vector additions was the most interesting because of the easy system of steps that need to be followed to solve problems. I really like when things are laid out clearly and the steps are easy to follow.

The most interesting material in this lecture was using unit vectors to easily add each component of a vector to find its total length.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the man and pulley example challenging, particularly the concept of two tensions (2T) acting in opposite directions. They struggled with understanding why the force pulling the man down is equal to the tension, and why the man needs to exert a force equal to his weight to stay still. The free body diagram for this scenario caused confusion, with students unsure about the source and direction of the tension vectors. Some students also found it unclear how to solve for variables in such problems.

the two tensions instead of one

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the use of positive and negative forces in FBDs**: While not explicitly mentioned, students' questions about the direction of gravity and tension suggest a need for clearer explanation. Emphasize that the choice of positive and negative directions is arbitrary but consistent within each FBD.

2. **Simplify complex pulley systems**: Break down complex pulley systems into simpler components to help students understand the doubling of tension forces. For example, in the man pulling himself up scenario, first explain the tension in the rope without the pulley, then introduce the pulley and explain how it affects the tension.

3. **Emphasize the importance of system boundaries**: To address students' confusion about which forces to include in FBDs, stress the importance of defining the system boundaries. Forces acting on objects within the system should be included, while forces acting on objects outside the system should not.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students grappled with creating and interpreting free body diagrams (FBDs), with tensions in pulley systems and multiple-mass interactions proving particularly challenging. Confusion arose from the arbitrary yet consistent choice of positive and negative directions for forces, the doubling of tension forces in pulleys, and identifying forces between objects. To enhance understanding, clarify the use of positive and negative forces, simplify complex pulley systems by breaking them down, and emphasize the importance of defining system boundaries to determine which forces to include in FBDs.

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion regarding the concept of tension, particularly in scenarios involving pulleys. They struggled to understand why tension is represented as positive, why there are two tensions in certain cases, and how to calculate these tensions. The relationship between tension and other forces, such as gravity and friction, also caused some confusion. Students found setting up free body diagrams challenging, especially when multiple objects were involved. They suggested clearer explanations of these concepts and more complex examples to better understand tension.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the Positive Representation of Tension**: Students' confusion about tension being represented as positive suggests a need for a clearer explanation of the sign convention used in free body diagrams. Consider dedicating a section to explain why tension is considered positive, even when it opposes gravity.

2. **Simplify the Concept of Multiple Tensions**: Instead of mentioning "two tensions" in general, break down the concept by explaining it specifically for pulley systems. Discuss the difference between the tension in the rope above the pulley (T1) and below it (T2), and how they are related (T1 = T2).

3. **Emphasize the Role of Tension in Free Body Diagrams**: To address students' struggle with understanding where tension comes into play, emphasize its role in free body diagrams. Explain that tension is used to represent the force exerted by a rope or string on an object, and it appears in the direction of the rope's pull.
refined_pred:
**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students grappled with understanding and applying the concept of tension, particularly in pulley systems and free body diagrams. Key areas of confusion included:

1. **Sign Convention of Tension**: Students struggled to comprehend why tension is represented as positive, even when it opposes gravity. A clearer explanation of the sign convention used in free body diagrams is needed.

2. **Multiple Tensions in Pulleys**: Students found it challenging to grasp the concept of two tensions (T1 and T2) in pulley systems and how they are related (T1 = T2). Breaking down this concept specifically for pulleys would be beneficial.

3. **Role of Tension in Free Body Diagrams**: Students had difficulty understanding where and how to include tension in free body diagrams. Emphasizing tension's role as the force exerted by a rope or string on an object, appearing in the direction of the rope's pull, could help clarify this.

Students suggested more complex examples and clearer explanations to better grasp these concepts. Addressing these areas will help students improve their understanding and application of tension in physics problems.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of the coefficient of friction engaging, with many appreciating its real-world applications and the interactive TopHat questions that explored it. They were intrigued by the idea that friction can be influenced by factors like temperature (cold vs. hot welds) and normal force, but not by surface area. The relationship between friction and the angle of incline, making pulling more efficient than pushing, was also a notable takeaway. Several students enjoyed calculating the coefficient of friction, with examples like the sandpaper block and the two-block pulley system being particularly enlightening. The molecular explanation of friction, involving cold welds and atomic interactions, was also found to be interesting and memorable.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Irrelevant Details**: Remove mentions of TopHat questions, breakout rooms, and other non-specific aspects to focus solely on the coefficient of friction. For example, "Students found the interactive questions engaging" can be omitted.

2. **Combine Similar Points**: Group together related student reflections to make the summary more concise. For instance, combine reflections on temperature, normal force, and surface area into one point about factors influencing friction.

3. **Use Student Quotes**: Incorporate direct quotes from students to make the summary more engaging and to highlight key points. For example, "One student noted, 'I found it interesting that surface area doesn't affect friction, only normal force and the friction coefficient matter.'"

**Revised Summary** (using the suggestions above):

SUMMARY: Students found the concept of the coefficient of friction captivating, appreciating its real-world applications and the opportunity to calculate it. They were intrigued by the idea that friction can be influenced by factors such as temperature ("cold vs. hot welds"), normal force, and the angle of incline ("pulling is more efficient than pushing"), but not by surface area ("surface area doesn't affect friction, only normal force and the friction coefficient matter," as one student noted). The relationship between friction and the angle of incline, making pulling more efficient than pushing, was also a notable takeaway. Many students enjoyed calculating the coefficient of friction, with examples like the sandpaper block and the two-block pulley system being particularly enlightening. The molecular explanation of friction, involving cold welds and atomic interactions, was also found to be interesting and memorable.

**Suggestions:**

The unique aspects of static friction, such as its dependence on applied force and being greater than kinetic friction, were particularly intriguing. Many struggled to understand why tension forces cannot be added together, as evidenced by comments like, "It was difficult to understand why the tensions don't add." Additionally, students found it challenging to determine the direction of tension forces, with some stating, "I was confused about the direction of the vectors" and "I was a little confused by the tension forces, specially figuring out which direction they go in." The tug of war problem, where students had to determine the tension force between two people pulling on a rope, was particularly confusing, with several students wanting clearer explanations of why the tension force fell between two values. Some students also found it difficult to apply Newton's laws to solve for different forces in the x and y directions.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found conceptual problems challenging, particularly those involving tension forces. Many struggled to relate real-life examples to theoretical concepts, with the tug of war and salami problems being notably confusing. The direction and calculation of forces, especially in multiple directions, caused difficulty. Some students also found Newton's laws and inertial reference frames conceptually demanding, with a need for clearer explanations and more practice problems.

Conceptual questions, such as the wrench in motion and the salami problem, also caused confusion due to their counterintuitive nature. Students struggled to apply Newton's Second Law equations in real-life scenarios, emphasizing the need for more relatable examples and practice problems. The distinction between inertial and non-inertial reference frames was another source of confusion, with students finding it difficult to visualize phantom forces. To improve understanding, students suggested more practice problems, clearer explanations of the laws' mathematical representations, and real-life examples that illustrate the principles of Newton's Laws.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on centripetal force problems engaging, with many appreciating the real-life applications and the opportunity to connect concepts to familiar scenarios. The discussion on terminal velocity, particularly the example of jumping from an airplane into water, was a standout, highlighting the danger of extreme accelerations and the role of drag force in different media. The exploration of uniform circular motion and the calculation of centripetal force also resonated with students, who enjoyed the practical aspects and the chance to apply formulas to novel situations. Some students were intrigued by the revelation that centripetal force is not a new force, but rather a result of other forces acting together. Overall, the lecture provided a solid foundation for understanding centripetal force problems, with students expressing enthusiasm for the topics covered.

1. **Eliminate repetitive phrases**: Instead of repeatedly mentioning "students found... interesting", combine instances where multiple students found the same topic engaging. For example, "Many students found the discussion on terminal velocity and the airplane jump example particularly captivating."

2. **Clarify the focus on centripetal force problems**: To make the summary more concise and focused on the topic, remove or merge sentences that discuss other topics (like drag force, uniform circular motion) without directly connecting them to centripetal force problems. For instance, combine the sentences about uniform circular motion and centripetal force calculation into one: "Students enjoyed exploring uniform circular motion and calculating centripetal force, appreciating the practical aspects and the chance to apply formulas to novel situations."

3. **Highlight the key takeaway**: To emphasize the learning outcome, end the summary with a sentence that encapsulates the main understanding students gained about centripetal force problems, e.g., "Through the lecture, students understood that centripetal force is not an independent force but a result of other forces acting together, providing a solid foundation for solving centripetal force problems."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Many students found the lecture on centripetal force problems engaging, with standout topics including the discussion on terminal velocity, particularly the airplane jump example, which highlighted the danger of extreme accelerations and the role of drag force in different media. Students enjoyed exploring uniform circular motion and calculating centripetal force, appreciating the practical aspects and the chance to apply formulas to novel situations. Through the lecture, students understood that centripetal force is not an independent force but a result of other forces acting together, providing a solid foundation for solving centripetal force problems.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of terminal velocity engaging, with many finding the real-life applications, such as jumping from an airplane, particularly interesting. The connection between drag force and terminal velocity was a key takeaway, with students appreciating the opportunity to calculate acceleration using only drag force. The concept that acceleration can occur even when velocity is constant, as seen in centripetal motion, also fascinated students.
input:
I thought the question of whether throwing something was faster than terminal velocity was interesting
What I found most interesting was how we were about to just use the terminal velocity equation until the drag force equation. 
Problems involving terminal velocity, drag
I thought that the skier and the pendulum free body diagrams were interesting, how the acceleration pointed towards the center
The first few top hat problems about the steel ball vs the ping pong ball. Interesting real life examples.
I find circular motion interesting because to me it just clicks in how to properly carry out a problem.
I thought the problem about hitting water at terminal velocity was very interesting. Finding out the immense acceleration experienced was a fun problem. 
The fact that there can be acceleration when velocity is is constant fascinates me. 
I found it interesting that even though earth has an acceleration, velocity can still become constant. 
I thought learning about uniform centripetal motion was really interesting. It was cool to learn how the different forces act on an object in centripetal motion.
 I found the centripetal force problems to be very interesting. I usually enjoy relating centripetal force to conceptual ideas, so I enjoyed that part of the lecture.
 I found centripetal force interesting today because I learned more about it than I did from the videos. 
 The most interesting thing in today's lecture was calculating the acceleration a person feels when they hit the water from jumping from an airplane.  It showed that the body cannot stand such a massive increase in acceleration .
 Extreme acceleration caused by terminal velocity into a body of water
 The final example about the centripetal force and acceleration .
 Why free falling at terminal velocity is dangerous. 
 When we compared the drag force and gravity from air to water
 I just like the fact that we are finally putting in air resistance as a factor... throughout high school we never would factor it in and I like learning about terminal velocity
 The explanation of centripetal force was interesting.
 The terminal velocity question was also kinda cool because it explained why you can't just jump into water safely at large heights. 
 I found it interesting for the terminal velocity and the acceleration is zero
 I found the explanation of drag force most interesting because it is a topic O have never covered before.
 I enjoyed learning about drag force, and real life applications. 
 explanation of centripetal force
 what was most interesting was talking about the impact of falling out of a plane
 Non uniform motion and how acceleration isn't always towards the center was interesting even if it wasn't explained in-depth.
 The question of the hanging ball will experience centripetal force.
 Top hat 
 I really enjoyed the plane question. I was a bit confused but it made me think of problems differently.
 I didn't know you can't jump out of an airplane into water, video games have indeed been lying.
 How you can calculate the acceleration using only drag force 
 the drag force causing an acceleration when entering a new fluid
 That Mg has to equal the Fd 
 I found the explanation of the airplane jump example interesting because I learned about drag force in water.
 the free body diagrams 
 I found the discussion about Pokémon and the exam format to be most interesting 
 The references to Pokémon and the references to Minecraft and how jumping into little to no water doesn't kill you
 I would say how you can use the drag force and terminal velocity and use them together like done in the water/air plane jump problem. 
 The real life applications to problems, increasing the time it takes for a collision to occur sets up energy stuff pretty well.
 it was interesting to see acceleration jumping from plane into water
 I think centripetal force is really interesting. It's so cool how something can go around a loop and not fall out
 The jumping out of a plane problem was the most interesting
 The water question with acceleration changing suddenly 
 Centripetal force isn't actually a new force.
 how you can use uniform circular motion even if the entire path is not a circle
 I thought the simulator for centripetal motion was really cool.
 the example with the puck, weight, and table and the cable car examples were interesting
 I enjoyed learning about terminal velocity and how to solve for it.
 I liked the terminal velocity stink bug example! That was cool to work through

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Redundancies**: Combine similar student reflections to make the summary more concise. For instance, instead of mentioning both "jumping from an airplane" and "hitting water at terminal velocity," you could combine them into "real-life applications, such as high-speed impacts with water."

2. **Clarify Key Concepts**: To better focus on terminal velocity problems, explicitly state that students found the equation for terminal velocity and its application intriguing. This could be phrased as: "Students found the equation for terminal velocity (v_t = √(2mg / ρA C_d)) and its application in solving real-life problems, like calculating the impact force when hitting water, particularly engaging."

3. **Highlight Drag Force Connection**: Emphasize the connection between drag force and terminal velocity as a significant learning point. This could be highlighted as: "The relationship between drag force and terminal velocity was a key takeaway, with students appreciating the opportunity to calculate acceleration using only drag force, as seen in problems involving changes in fluid density."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the topic of terminal velocity problems engaging, with many appreciating the opportunity to apply the equation for terminal velocity (v_t = √(2mg / ρA C_d)) to real-life scenarios, such as high-speed impacts with water. The relationship between drag force and terminal velocity was a key takeaway, with students finding it intriguing that acceleration can occur even when velocity is constant, as seen in centripetal motion and changes in fluid density.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on acceleration engaging, with several key points resonating with them. The concept of acceleration not always being towards the center in non-uniform motion was intriguing, as was the idea that acceleration can occur even when velocity is constant, such as when an object is moving at terminal velocity. The application of these concepts to real-life scenarios, like jumping from an airplane into water, was particularly captivating. Students also enjoyed learning about centripetal force and its role in circular motion, with the centripetal force problems and the explanation of centripetal force being highlighted as interesting aspects of the lecture.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate repetitive phrases**: Instead of repeatedly mentioning "students found... interesting", use phrases like "students' interest was sparked by...", "students were intrigued by...", or simply "students found... notable". This will make the summary more concise.

   *Original*: "Students found... interesting", "Students found... interesting", "Students found... interesting"
   *Revised*: "Students' interest was sparked by...", "Students were intrigued by...", "Students found... notable"

2. **Combine similar points**: Group similar reflections together to make the summary more focused and less repetitive. For instance, combine reflections about terminal velocity and acceleration under constant velocity.

   *Original*: "The fact that there can be acceleration when velocity is constant fascinates me." (separate from other terminal velocity reflections)
   *Revised*: "Students were fascinated by the concept of acceleration occurring at terminal velocity, where velocity remains constant."

3. **Use transitional phrases**: To improve the flow of the summary, use transitional phrases to connect related points. This will make the summary more coherent and easier to follow.

   *Original*: "The application of these concepts to real-life scenarios...", "Students also enjoyed learning about centripetal force..."
   *Revised*: "Moreover, students were captivated by the application of these acceleration concepts to real-life scenarios, such as jumping from an airplane into water. Similarly, students found the exploration of centripetal force and its role in circular motion engaging."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students' interest was sparked by the lecture on acceleration, with several key concepts resonating with them. They were intrigued by the idea that acceleration is not always directed towards the center in non-uniform motion and that it can occur even when velocity is constant, such as when an object is moving at terminal velocity. Students were fascinated by the concept of acceleration occurring at terminal velocity, where velocity remains constant, and the potential dangers it poses, as illustrated by the example of jumping from an airplane into water. Moreover, students were captivated by the application of these acceleration concepts to real-life scenarios, such as jumping from an airplane into water. Similarly, students found the exploration of centripetal force and its role in circular motion engaging, with the centripetal force problems and the explanation of centripetal force being notable aspects of the lecture.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Focus on Key Drag Force Concepts**: Instead of mentioning every interesting aspect, highlight only those related to drag force. For instance, combine the points about acceleration at terminal velocity and entering a new fluid into a single sentence: "Students found it fascinating that drag force can cause significant acceleration, even at constant velocity, as demonstrated by the sudden change in acceleration when entering water."

2. **Clarify the Airplane Jump Example**: Instead of mentioning the airplane jump example twice, combine the points: "The airplane jump problem stood out to students as it showcased the practical application of using drag force and terminal velocity together to calculate the immense acceleration experienced upon hitting water."

3. **Remove Less Relevant Points**: To make the summary more concise and focused, remove points that are less related to drag force problems, such as the mention of centripetal force problems and uniform circular motion. These could be addressed in a separate summary if necessary.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on drag force problems engaging, with key concepts resonating. They appreciated learning that drag force can cause significant acceleration, even at constant velocity, as demonstrated by the sudden change in acceleration when entering water. The airplane jump problem stood out, showcasing the practical application of using drag force and terminal velocity together to calculate the immense acceleration experienced upon hitting water. Students also found it insightful to use the drag force equation in conjunction with the terminal velocity equation to solve real-world problems.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on the Right-Hand Rule clear and informative, with practice problems and demonstrations like the car example aiding comprehension. However, many students expressed confusion about applying the rule on a 2D graph and determining the direction of the result. Some struggled with understanding when the rule points in or out of the screen. Several students suggested more detailed explanations and examples to clarify these aspects.
input:
The right-hand rule and how to use coordinate plane with just x and z values (as opposed to x and y).
I found everything to be fairly straightforward during today's lecture. Graphs of derivatives confused me a bit, so maybe more time could be spent on that.
The explanations of the cross product were very informative, and the practice problems really helped to clarify the topic
I thought today's lecture was very clear. I appreciated the car demonstration, as well as the Top Hat questions. It helped me stay engaged and better understand the topics covered.
I could follow along easily in this lecture. One thing that could've used more explaining was the right hand rule top hat question. 
Everything was clear during this lecture. I had no confusion and I understood everything from the clicker questions. 
I was quite confused with the x,y,a, axis top hat question. I didnt quite understand the placement of the z axis (axis coming out/into the screen). 
My zoom was not working well today so it was not easy paying attention to the lecture as it kept freezing. the only thing that I would want more details in would be the way an object is 3-D on paper because i still do not get that
Cross products and into vs out of screen.
It was unclear how much time we would have in our groups to answer the tophat questions.
 I am a little confused about the last example we were doing, but when I thought over after class, I figured out the answers.
 right hand method. I will never understand. The top hat question about that rule made no sense to me. 
 Drawing position, velocity, and acceleration graphs. I had trouble with this in high school and still do not fully understand it 
 The one problem where the hypotenuse was facing the wrong direction was a little confusing at first. It went right over my head when I did the problem. The explanation for it was very good though. 
 the derivation and explanation of formulas for acceleration and velocity could've been covered and used in examples more
 i was still a little confused about the position velocity and acceleration graphs. i always get confused when interpreting them. i'll definitely go watch some youtube videos about it but it would go a little more in depth

 Top hat questions the end ones in particular

 The position, velocity, and acceleration graphs we touched on at the end of class were a little confusing, specifically the position graph. We only talked about it for a little bit at the end of class so I'm sure with more practice I will be able to understand the concept a lot better.
 I think how to calculate the angles (right hand rule) and the negative vs positive vector could be a explained a little bit more? The videos were super helpful of course but it'd be nice to know for sure that I understand it correctly :)

 Cross products are confusing when determining the directions of the vectors but practice problems can really help. 
 I thought today's lecture was great! I enjoyed having tricky vector problems with the tails not matching. I am confused by the going backwards from acceleration to velocity and would like more examples of that. 
 The cross product was a little confusing because I didn't know where to apply it in terms of physics.
 direction of result when using cross product

 I need more details on how to graphically change from displacement to velocity and acceleration.
 The position, velocity and acceleration graphs were very confusing. Also, I understood the dot and cross methods when doing the lecture videos and homework problems, but when working in breakout groups today, everyone in my group was going about the problem a different way which confused me. 
 I didn't quite understand the explanation of why the acceleration was positive when the car went up and back down the ramp since it had to stop to change direction.
